+    /**
+     * The Commit Block List operation writes a blob by specifying the list of block IDs that make up the blob.
+     * In order to be written as part of a blob, a block must have been successfully written to the server in a prior
+     * Put Block operation. You can call Put Block List to update a blob by uploading only those blocks that have
+     * changed, then committing the new and existing blocks together. You can do this by specifying whether to commit
+     * a block from the committed block list or from the uncommitted block list, or to commit the most recently uploaded
+     * version of the block, whichever list it may belong to.
+     *
+     * @param containerName  The container name.
+     * @param blobName       The blob name.
+     * @param base64BlockIds The block IDs.

replies.bodyText: It was a preparation for the work of merging TransferClient APIs to StorageClient, similar to what iOS did, i.e. we want to discourage users from using raw GET APIs and encourage to use "managed" download. I'm not completely happy with this name though.
replies.author: anuchandy

replies.bodyText: Would it be a bad idea to keep download for both clients but to encourage people to use the managed operation both in the documentation and code samples? Any thoughts on this @bsiegel?
replies.author: vcolin7

replies.bodyText: Oh nevermind, looking at your other PR (#241) I piucked up on what you mean by merging both clients. I think having two different names is good, while I also feel there might be something better than the raw prefix.

timeline.body:
Java has two distinct types: [`BlobDownloadResponse`](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-java/blob/master/sdk/storage/azure-storage-blob/src/main/java/com/azure/storage/blob/models/BlobDownloadResponse.java) and [`BlobDownloadAsyncResponse`](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-java/blob/master/sdk/storage/azure-storage-blob/src/main/java/com/azure/storage/blob/models/BlobDownloadAsyncResponse.java). I originally decided to go for the latter because our use case lined up with what Java has.

Do you think we will add something like Java's `BlobDownloadResponse` where no ResponseBody is returned but rather written to something like an `OutputStream`? I tend to think so.

timeline.bodyHTML:
Java has two distinct types: BlobDownloadResponse and BlobDownloadAsyncResponse. I originally decided to go for the latter because our use case lined up with what Java has.

Do you think we will add something like Java's BlobDownloadResponse where no ResponseBody is returned but rather written to something like an OutputStream? I tend to think so.
timeline.author: vcolin7

replies.bodyText:
Right, Java has BlobDownloadAsyncResponse to support Flux that asynchronously streams the bytes from the connection, so the text "async" in the model indicates that it composes "async" Flux.
In the Android case, BlobDownloadAsyncResponse  was composing ResponseBody that exposes InputStream from which we can "synch"-ronously read the bytes from the connection. This is why I removed the text "async", in addition to that, it looks also weird when that type listed in the JavaDoc with our other Response types.
replies.author: anuchandy

replies.bodyText: Since the decision to read the bytes synchronously would come down to us, do you think there could be a point where we would want to go the fully async route with ResponseBody? (i.e. using byteStream).
replies.author: vcolin7
anuchandy

replies.bodyText: Does this mean we won't be able to asynchronously read content if we are using OkHttp?
replies.author: vcolin7

replies.bodyText: yes, OkHttp is natively built on blocking socket not based on selectable channel(e.g. netty). But it should be fine in the mobile space, even if we use native UrlConnection (like android SDK from other cloud providers), it still sync. I think we don't have to worry about it at least now (the user can still read from IS on demand instead of buffering).
replies.author: anuchandy
